                                • Chapter 4 Exercise 5

                                Connectedness

                                4.36

                                Prove that a metric space S is disconnected if, and only if, there is a nonempty subset A of S, A≠S, which is both open and closed in S.

                                Proof

                                If S is disconnected, then there exist nonempty open sets A and B such that S=A∪B and A∩B=∅, we claim A is also closed, let p∉A, then p∈B, since B is open, there is some r>0 such that B(p;r)⊆B, as A∩B=∅, this means p is not an accumulation point of A. Thus all accumulation point of A lies in A.

                                Conversely, if there is A not empty, A≠S such that A is both closed and open, let B=S−A, then S=A∪B and A∩B=∅, from A being closed we know B is open, and we conclude S is disconnected.

                                4.37

                                Prove that a metric space S is connected if, and only if, the only subsets of S which are both open and closed in S are the empty set and S itself.

                                Proof

                                If S is connected, and assume there exist A⊆S which is both open and closed in S, but neither empty nor S itself, then A satisfy the condition in Exercise 4.36, we can say S is disconnected and get a contradiction. Conversely, if the only subsets of S which are both open and closed in S are the empty set and S itself, then S must be connected, otherwise we can find some nonempty subset A of S, A≠S, which is both open and closed in S.

                                4.38

                                Prove that the only connected subsets of R are (a) the empty set, (b) sets consisting of a single point, and (c) intervals (open, closed, half-open, or infinite).

                                Proof

                                It is easy to verify (a),(b) and (c) are connected subsets. To see these are the only subsets of R, we only need to prove if S is connected and a,b∈S,a≠b, then all points between a and b belong to S. Suppose a<b and c∈(a,b) with c∉S, then let A=(−∞,c)∩S and B=(c,+∞)∩S, we have A∪B=S, since a∈A and b∈B, both A and B are nonempty, obviously A∩B=∅ and both are open in S, this means S is disconnected, a contradiction.

                                4.39

                                Let X be a connected subset of a metric space S. Let Y be a subset of S such that X⊆Y⊆X―, where X― is the closure of X. Prove that Y is also connected. In particular, this shows that X― is connected.

                                Proof

                                Let f be a two-value function on Y, then f is constant on X since X is connected. Suppose f(x)=c,x∈X, for y∈Y,y∉X, we see that y is an accumulation point of X, if f(y)≠c, then f cannot be continuous at y, a contradiction. Thus f(x)=c for x∈Y, this means Y is connected.

                                4.40

                                If x is a point in a metric space S, let U(x) be the component of S containing x. Prove that U(x) is closed in S.

                                Proof

                                Let p be an accumulation point of U(x) and let f be a two-value function on U(x)∪{p}, we shall prove f is constant and the set U(x)∪{p} is connected, by definition of U(x) it means p∈U(x). Suppose f(x)=c on U(x), as p is an accumulation point of U(x), we can find some {xn} approaches p close enough such that |f(p)−f(xn)|<ε for any ε>0, it follows that f(p)=c, and the proof is complete.

                                4.41

                                Let S be an open subset of R. By Theorem 3.11, S is the union of a countable disjoint collection of open intervals in R. Prove that each of these open intervals is a component of the metric subspace S. Explain why this does not contradict Exercise 4.40.

                                Proof

                                Let S=⋃n=1∞In. By Exercise 4.38, each of these open interval In is connected, and In∩Im=∅ if n≠m. Assume some In is not a component of S, then we can find some component U of S such that In⊊U, since In itself is connected. Let x∈U−In, consider U(x) which is the component of S containing x, as x∈U, we have U(x)⊆U, as x∈S,x∉In, we can find some m≠n such that x∈Im, then Im and U are two connected sets both contain x, so U∪Im⊆U(x)⊆U, we can get Im⊆U. This means In∪Im⊆U, we can further deduce In∪Im⊆int U, since U⊆S, U contains at least two distinct open intervals, U is an interval in R, thus int U is an open interval belonging to S, and In⊊int U, it contradicts the definition of component interval (In is a component interval means no open interval J≠In can have In⊆J⊆S, but int U does).

                                This does not contradict Exercise 4.40 since each In is open in R but not open relative to S.

                                4.42

                                Given a compact set S in Rn with the following property: For every pair of points a and b in S and for every ε>0 there exists a finite set of points {x0,x1,…,xn} in S with x0=a and xn=b such that

                                ∥xk−xk−1∥<ε,k=1,2,…,n

                                Prove or disprove: S is connected.

                                Proof

                                Assume S is not connected, then there exist nonempty disjoint open sets A and B such that S=A∩B. Choose a∈A and b∈B, we form two sequences {yn} in A and {zn} in B like this: for n∈N, we can find a finite set of points {x0=a,x1,…,xm=b} in S such that ∥xk−xk−1∥<1/n, since A∩B=∅, we select some k such that xk∈A and xk+1∈B, it is always possible to find such a k since x0∈A and xm∈B. We let yn=xk and zn=xk+1, then ∥yn−zn∥<1/n for all n. As S is compact, both {yn} and {zn} has convergent subsequence which converges in S, let ynk→y and znk→z, since both A and B are closed in S (by Exercise 4.36), we have y∈A and z∈B, thus y≠z. Consider y∈A, we can find a ball B(y;r)⊆A as A is open, thus there are no points of B in this ball, but if we choose N enough such that 1/N<r/2, there exist K such that nK>N and ∥ynK−y∥<r/2, this means

                                ∥znK−y∥≤∥znK−ynK∥+∥ynK−y∥<1nK+r2<r

                                thus znK∈B(y;r)⊆A, a contradiction to A∩B=∅.

                                4.43

                                Prove that a metric space S is connected if, and only if, every nonempty proper subset of S has a nonempty boundary.

                                Proof

                                If S is connected, assume there is A⊊S which is nonempty but has empty boundary, let B=S−A, since ∂A=A―∩B―=∅, we have A∩B―=∅, thus if a∈A, then a is not an accumulation point of B, meaning there is a ball B(a;r) which has no points of B, thus a is an interior point of A, it means A is open, similarly we can prove B is open. Now from A∪B=S and A∩B=∅ we deduce S being disconnected, a contradiction.

                                Conversely, if every nonempty proper subset of S has a nonempty boundary. Assume S is disconnected and A,B be nonempty open sets in S which satisfy A∩B=∅ and A∪B=S, then A is a proper subset of S since B is nonempty, and ∂A must be empty, since any point belongs to ∂A must belong to either A or B since A∪B=S, but belonging to A means it cannot belong to B― as A is open, and vice versa. We obtain a nonempty proper subset of S which has empty boundary, a contradiction.

                                4.44

                                Prove that every convex subset of Rn is connected.

                                Proof

                                A convex subset of Rn is arcwise connected.

                                4.45

                                Given a function f:Rn→Rm which is one-to-one and continuous on Rn. If A is open and disconnected in Rn, prove that f(A) is open and disconnected in f(Rn).

                                Proof

                                f(A) is open by the continuity of f. Since A is disconnected, we have A=B∪S for open set B and S with B∩S=∅. Both f(B) and f(S) are open, and f(B)∩f(S)=∅ since f is one-to-one, obviously f(B)∪f(S)=f(A). Thus f(A) is disconnected.

                                4.46

                                Let A={(x,y):0<x≤1,y=sin⁡1/x},B={(x,y):y=0,−1≤x≤0}, and let S=A∪B. Prove that S is connected but not arcwise connected.

                                Proof

                                To see S is connected, let f be a two-value function on S, then f is constant on A and constant on B, since two points both in A can be arbitrarily close, so is two points in B. Also notice that (0,0)∈B is an accumulation point of A, thus we can select a∈A which is close enough to (0,0), thus f(a)=f(0,0). It follows that S is a connected set.

                                To see S is not arcwise connected, assume there is a continuous function f:[0,1]→S such that f(0)=(0,0) and f(1)=(1,sin⁡1), then for ε=1/2, there is a δ>0 such that ∥f(x)−(0,0)∥<ε whenever 0<x<δ, choose N large enough so that 1/(2Nπ)<δ, let

                                p=12Nπ,q=1(2N+1)π,r=1(2N+12)π

                                define S′=f([q,p]), then S′ is connected since the interval [q,p] is connected in [0,1] and f is continuous. we define

                                U={(x,y):x<r}∩S′,V={(x,y):x>r}∩S′

                                then U,V are open in S since {(x,y):x<r} and {(x,y):x>r} are open in R2, and U∩V=∅, to see U∪V=S′, notice when x=r, the only point possibly in S is the point (r,1)∈S, but (r,1)∉S′ since ∥f(x)∥<1/2 whenever x∈[q,p], since the point (p,0)∈U and (q,0)∈V, both U and V are nonempty, we conclude the set S′ is disconnected, a contradiction.

                                4.47

                                Let F={F1,F2,…} be a countable collection of connected compact sets in Rn such that Fk+1⊆Fk for each k≥1. Prove that the intersection ⋂k=1∞Fk is connected and closed.

                                Proof

                                If some Fi is empty, then ⋂k=1∞Fk is empty and there is nothing to prove. Suppose Fn≠∅ for all n, since compact sets in Rn are closed and bounded, use the Cantor intersection theorem we can see ⋂k=1∞Fk is closed and nonempty, thus compact.

                                The proof that ⋂k=1∞Fk is connected is left TO BE DONE.

                                4.48

                                Let S be an open connected set in Rn. Let T be a component of Rn−S. Prove that Rn−T is connected.

                                4.49

                                Let (S,d) be a connected metric space which is not bounded. Prove that for every a in S and every r>0, the set {x:d(x,a)=r} is nonempty.

                                Proof

                                Assume there exist a∈S,r>0 such that the set {x:d(x,a)=r} is empty. Then we define

                                A={x∈S:d(x,a)<r},B={x∈S:d(x,a)>r}

                                Since d(a,a)=0<r, we have a∈A, if B=∅, then S=A, which means S is bounded, but the condition says S is not bounded, thus B is nonempty. Obviously both A and B are open, and A∪B=S and A∩B=∅, then S is disconnected, a contradiction.
